text: That's a wrap! Thanks to @dataeditor and @ZivaBranstetter for joining us. You can watch the full talk on Facebook:‚Ä¶ https://t.co/ujyludhahV
.@ZivaBranstetter's Qs to ask about an investigative idea: Is there actual harm? Is it new? If someone‚Äôs done it can you do it better?
.@dataeditor: In the pre-reporting process ask yourself
column4: what‚Äôs the minimum story and what‚Äôs the maximum story you can get?

text: .@ZivaBranstetter: Be practiced in the art of pre-reporting to focus an investigation before you pursue a full-fledged investigation.
.@ZivaBranstetter: Constantly be gathering data. There‚Äôs a data component as part of every investigation
column4: from spreadsheets to timelines.

text: .@dataeditor: I try and fight for everything. It‚Äôs about knowing what battles are winnable. Part of stories can be records won't be supplied
.@ZivaBranstetter: Find unique ways to get the latest data possible for a project
column4: including surveying people and cold calling.

text: After a project
column4: ask: What's changed? Are things better or worse? There's no shame in doing an investigation again from a different angle.

text: .@ZivaBranstetter: After an investigation is published
column4: track the impact of it and keep in touch with sources for updates on the story.

text: .@dataeditor: There‚Äôs not a punishment for violating open records laws
column4: and there should be when records are in the public interest.

text: .@ZivaBranstetter: Take advantage of resources like @rcfp if you're a smaller news organization and need to sue for documents
column4: data

text: .@ZivaBranstetter: Civil rights attorneys can be a good source for investigations. Also Twitter-shaming to hold people accountable.
One of @dataeditor's workarounds to getting more data: Family members of victims can help share data or documents with you.
One of @ZivaBranstetter's must-read recommendations: An investigative collaboration by @ProPublica and @MarshallProj https://t.co/q6sX8WlVIC
One of @dataeditor's suggestions for a must-read investigation: @CIRonline‚Äôs investigative series on Instagram: https://t.co/M55ndcit2M.
.@ZivaBranstetter: Go into each project thinking about who your audience is and how you're going to reach them. Must be intentional.
.@ZivaBranstetter: Know which platform to tell your story on
column4: what you're good at and how to partner with people.

text: Tips for young journalists: Get really good at one or two things and be okay at everything else. You need to be a jack of one or two trades.
.@dataeditor: Data and documents can lie. While they‚Äôre very
column4: very important
column5: they‚Äôre just one piece of an investigative reporter‚Äôs arsenal.

text: .@dataeditor: "Numbers tend to bog down what can be elegant narratives and the impact of a story. Not every analysis is illuminating."
.@ZivaBranstetter: persistence is key when it comes to obtaining hard to get documents.
We'll be sharing tips from @ZivaBranstetter
column4: who's investigated the death penalty
